items.title: Consider releasing new minor version
items.body:
PyPI page still refer to wrong docs location. It looks weird a little bit.
This was fixed already in trunk, but not released.

items.title: configurage RTD to use rtd.txt
items.body:
@cguardia @mcdonc @mmerickel @blaflamme would one of you owners of the RTD configuration please add "rtd.txt", or add me as an owner? Thank you!
https://readthedocs.org/projects/translationstring/

items.title: the u prefix is not valid on py32
items.body:
The new release is breaking the pyramid tests on py32.

https://github.com/Pylons/translationstring/commit/3c64ef3b9a09117df5f235e42183fe5b82ffe4a6

items.title: Cannot pass TranslationString as mapping value to TranslationString
items.body:
The Problem is that there is no way to embedd translated strings inside a translated string. Thus something like _('${foo}', mapping={'foo': _('bar')}) does not work.

This problem arises in frameworks like pyramid where the actual translation of the strings is handled later and not where the translated string is defined thus making it hard to build up translated strings programmatically.

One example we had was a superclass that defines some rules for a game and then a subclass that would have liked to extend those rules by adding to them. But I haven't yet found a way to get those translated strings to combine correctly.

items.title: can not specify mapping when translation
items.body:
I have code that looks like this:

``` python
MAIL_BODY = _(
u'Hello ${name},\n'
u'\n'
u'Welcome to our service! Lorem ipsum etc. etc.')

def welcome(request):
    translate = get_localizer(request).translate
    user = get_user(request)
    body = translate(MAIL_BODY, mapping={'name': user.title()})
```

This moves the (often quite large) texts outside of the code to another place, making the code easier to read. But this does not work: translationstring.translator ignores its mapping argument if the tstring already is a translationstring instance.

My gut feeling is that translator() should always use the domain and mapping arguments, possibly overriding those of an existing tstring. As far as I can see this will not break any existing code.
